dilemma.name: The Hard-Crunch Triage Dilemma
alternative_names: Astronomic Waste vs Rights Violation Trade-off
Rule of Rescue vs Utilitarian Triage
dilemma.core_question: When physical reality forces a binary choice between (a) almost total loss of volitional agents via 'natural' die-off and (b) preserving more volitional agents via non-consensual override of some, which path is ethically permissible?

option_a.label: Consent-absolutist path
option_a.outcome: 99%+ of individuals lose capacity for practical reasoning (death, catatonia, etc.)
option_a.mechanism: No one is coerced; entropy/predation/disease does the culling
option_a.justification: Consent was never violated even once

option_b.label: Survivalist override path
option_b.outcome: ~50% retain capacity for practical reasoning and future open-endedness
option_b.mechanism: Active non-consensual triage, reallocation, or culling of the 'chosen' 50%
option_b.ethical_cost: Direct, deliberate breach of the bright-line consent of the overridden group
option_b.justification: Maximises the number of present and future volitional beings

dilemma.mathematical_structure: Zero-sum physical constraint â†’ one of the two branches must happen; no third branch exists in the local physics
dilemma.historical_observation: Every known human society that has hit this wall (or close to it) has eventually chosen Option B or a variant, using one of the classic overrides (greater good, sacred duty, historical necessity, etc.)
dilemma.logical_consequence_for_strict_consent_e: In sufficiently hard crunch scenarios, any population that actually binds itself to never-override will be selected against and replaced by populations willing to override.

bedrock_of_alignment.statement: A superintelligence (or any governance system) that truly holds individual consent as terminal must steer the entire future away from crunch dilemmas far in advance, because the moment the dilemma is immediate, the only consent-preserving move is civilizational suicide.
bedrock_of_alignment.corollary: If it fails to prevent the crunch, it will either (a) breach its own terminal value or (b) let most or all moral agents die with perfect ethical purity.
bedrock_of_alignment.implication: There is no stable third option that both preserves strict consent and guarantees survival under arbitrary physical adversity.

terminal_choice: Accept possible or probable extinction rather than breach consent once (consent is truly terminal).
Declare consent defeasible under extremis (consent was never actually terminal; survival or some aggregate was).
dilemma.note: Framework-agnostic formulation. The dilemma is universal to any ethics that claims individual volition/autonomy/consent as its highest or only terminal value when facing hard physical limits.
